review.title: Learning from Clinical Judgments: Semi-Markov-Modulated Marked Hawkes Processes for Risk Prognosis
review.abstract: Critically ill patients in regular wards are vulnerable to unanticipated adverse events which require prompt transfer to the intensive care unit (ICU). To allow for accurate prognosis of deteriorating patients, we develop a novel continuous-time probabilistic model for a monitored patient's temporal sequence of physiological data. Our model captures "informatively sampled" patient episodes: the clinicians' decisions on when to observe a hospitalized patient's vital signs and lab tests over time are represented by a marked Hawkes process, with intensity parameters that are modulated by the patient's latent clinical states, and with observable physiological data (mark process) modeled as a switching multi-task Gaussian process. In addition, our model captures "informatively censored" patient episodes by representing the patient's latent clinical states as an absorbing semi-Markov jump process. The model parameters are learned from offline patient episodes in the electronic health records via an EM-based algorithm. Experiments conducted on a cohort of patients admitted to a major medical center over a 3-year period show that risk prognosis based on our model significantly outperforms the currently deployed medical risk scores and other baseline machine learning algorithms.

sections.heading: 4.2. The Real-time Risk Scoring Algorithm
sections.text: After learning the model parameters from an offline dataset D, we now explain how the risk scoring is performed in real time for a newly admitted patient. The patient risk score at the time t is defined by R (t) and is defined as R (t) = P (X (∞) = N | {ym, tm}, tm ≤ t,...). That is, the risk score R (t) is the probability that in the deteriorating state N, taking into account observable physiological data up to a time. On the basis of the Bayes rule, the risk score R (t) is calculated based on the efficient (dynamic programming algorithm) forward filtered algorithm, while the "future transition period" is calculated based on the estimated parameters.

sections.heading: 5. Experiments
sections.text: To evaluate the prognostic benefits of our model, we conducted experiments with a data set D containing information on patient admissions to a major medical center over a 3-year period, and compared the risk value defined in Section 4.2 with other competing baselines. In the next section, we briefly describe our data set and then present the experimental results. A very detailed description of our data set and baseline implementation can be found in Appendix D of the supplementary material.

sections.heading: 5.1. Data Description
sections.text: The patient cohort in D is very heterogeneous; diagnoses include sepsis, high blood pressure, kidney failure, leukemia, septicaemia and pneumonia. Each patient's episode in D includes 21 vital signs and laboratory tests collected for the patient over time, as well as the intervals in which they were collected. Vital signs include diastolic and systolic blood pressure, Glasgow coma scale, heart rate, eye opening, respiratory rate, temperature, oxygen saturation and device support, best motor and verbal responses. Laboratory tests included measurements of chloride, glucose, urea, white blood cells, creatine, hemoglobin, platelet count, potassium, sodium and CO2. In all experiments conducted in this section, we divided D into a training kit consisting of 2.5 years admissions (5,000 years, platelets, haemocytes, globum, and CO2).

sections.heading: 5.2. Results
sections.text: We have extended the offline learning algorithm in Subsection 4.1 (with 1000 EM iterations) to the 5,000 training episodes in D and obtained an estimate for the semi-markovmodulated labeled Hawkes process describing the patient cohort. By means of the Rothkes clinical process, clinical deterioration of our model with 4 clinical states is selected, with state 1 being clinical stability (absorbing), and state 4 being clinical deterioration (absorbing) state. The learned Hawkes process functions for these two states are given byλ (t, 1) = 0.55 patient intensity in 4 clinical states where clinical deterioration (absorbing) is added.

sections.heading: 6. Discussion: Chicken-and-egg
sections.text: We emphasize that in calculating our risk score for the test phases, we have not used the information provided in the observation process to infer the clinical condition of patients. This is because the value of the real-time risk score R (t) itself influences the physician's behavior and therefore influences the observation process, creating a chicken-and-egg dilemma in which the causal relationship between the risk score and the physician's assessments cannot be clearly determined. A very interesting direction of research is to consider an observation process that is modulated both by the patient's condition and the real-time risk score by an intensity function (t, X (t), R (t)), in which the algorithm learns the clinical status representation online by sharing experiences with physicians. That is, the algorithm uses the clinical condition assessments to refine the clinical condition model, resulting in a more refined risk score.

metadata.abstractText: Critically ill patients in regular wards are vulnerable to unanticipated adverse events which require prompt transfer to the intensive care unit (ICU). To allow for accurate prognosis of deteriorating patients, we develop a novel continuoustime probabilistic model for a monitored patient’s temporal sequence of physiological data. Our model captures “informatively sampled” patient episodes: the clinicians’ decisions on when to observe a hospitalized patient’s vital signs and lab tests over time are represented by a marked Hawkes process, with intensity parameters that are modulated by the patient’s latent clinical states, and with observable physiological data (mark process) modeled as a switching multi-task Gaussian process. In addition, our model captures “informatively censored” patient episodes by representing the patient’s latent clinical states as an absorbing semi-Markov jump process. The model parameters are learned from offline patient episodes in the electronic health records via an EM-based algorithm. Experiments conducted on a cohort of patients admitted to a major medical center over a 3-year period show that risk prognosis based on our model significantly outperforms the currently deployed medical risk scores and other baseline machine learning algorithms.
